text: ip tested +ve for covid ip tested +ve for covid. ip hasn't been in office since the start of the christmas break. line manager in contact

ip agrivated pre-existing back injury opening slide door engie project - cygnus alpha - injured party (ip) who had previous history of lumbar problems opened a sliding door, located cellar deck plant room (technicians office) on cygnus pu on monday 28th march at 13:30. he reported that this door required effort to open it; he felt the pain immediately on opening the sliding door.he reported this incident to the sea fox 2 medic on tuesday 29th march at 09:00. the seafox 2 medic examined him and after consultation with topside doctor gave him prescription strength medication and sent ashore to be seen by topside medical services wrightway health based in norwich.   •	sliding door operation checked and found to be free moving and easy to open.•	door secured open as a precaution in-case of intermittent issue with the door mechanism.•	witness statement recorded and ip medevacced for further consultation with onshore doctor

category: foot or leg injury, fuel spill or leak
text: prime mover making delivery of service truck on low loader from hq3 to wpa lost traction descending tokaju hill resulting in jack-knife. truck and trailer came to rest in drain.  damage sustained to fuel tank resulting in leakage.  no injuries migrated from legacy cairs incident #34031note:late report into cairs due to intranet beingdown. no access to cairs.backgroundwg hgcp construction projects provide the angore project transportation support of plant, equipment and material between the hides gas conditioning plant (hgcp) and hq3 workshop (in the vicinity a short distance from hgcp on the spineline) to and from the angore well pad a (wpa). the distance between hgcp and wpa is approximately 27 kms. although a short distance, this journey takes over one hour to complete given the terrain to be covered. on this day a heavy equipment operator (heo) had been assigned to transport a laurini service vehicle from hq3 to wpa operating a mercedes prime mover (pp110) with a low loader (pp083). the heo had been assigned a vehicle escort driver (ed) to provide safe passage for the journey. the environmentthe roadway from hgcp to wpa is not sealed and presents many challenges to the vehicle and driver due to hill ascents and descents, tight corners, potholes, sheer drops off cliff edges, commercial enterprises set up on the roadway sides, wet weather and the human and animal hazards that can suddenly appear. the terrain can test vehicle and mobile plant build quality where a component failure and / or operator error can and has resulted in deaths to vehicle occupants and other road users. vehicle build quality and maintenance programs are key to the reliability and safe use of vehicles in the southern highlands as is driver competency and behaviours. tokaju hill is especially steep and has seen many traffic incidents. tokaju hill is lined with old large plant tyres on one side as a last line of defence to prevent vehicle / plant rollover. deep spoon drains are installed on both sides of the road. the road is cambered to both spoon drains .(ref: photo no.2)tokaju hill had been graded as recent as the 8th june by a local maintenance team leaving a loosely bound top surface of approximately 50mm. that and the consistent heavy rain in the evenings prior had made the road surface slippery. on this day weather conditions at the time were good with no rain.the operatorthe heo has been employed by wg since the 13th oct 2014 (2yrs 8mts) at hgcp. the heo had been verified as competent to operate medium ridged vehicles and heavy combination vehicles in october 2014 and has been operating such vehicles since. the heo is held in high regard amongst his supervisors as a capable operator and has clean employment recordthe heo had been 11 days into a 4 week rotation. this is a journey the heo has completed many times before without incident. the vehiclemercedes benz prime mover (pp110). serviced on a monthly basis (last service 19/05/17) and is within service date. the truck is operational conditionrisk assessmenta prestart meeting was held by the supervisor that morning with the heodiscussing the transportation of equipment from hq3 to wpathe heo completed a prestart on the truck covering the safety systems, a visual check of tyres, inspection of fluids, inspection of the truck body and general check of the vehicle. the jsa for semi-trailer and low loader duties was reviewed and signed on to by the heo. the jsa does not identify encountering poor road conditions as a hazardthe heo completed the human machine interface swp checklist. incident detailsbetween 10:10 & 10:30hrs the heo in the prime mover with low loader and ed departed hq3 to wpa to deliver a laurini service vehicle. approximately 30-45 minutes into the journey the escort driver (ed) stopped at the base of tokaju hill (as per standard operating procedure) to control traffic and allow safe passage for the heo to descend the hill. a pmv bus approached and the ed held the pmv at the base of the hill. prior to descending tokaju hill, the heo engaged 1st gear and diff lock. on decent, the heo went to press the brakes however could did not sense the truck slowing down. the wheels of the low loader had locked and started to slide. after approximately 70m of travel the trailer slid into a storm water drain with the prime mover jack-knifing into the trailer. this caused contact with the trucks fuel tank resulting in a hole approx. 75mm diameter in the diesel fuel tank and subsequent leak to grade of approximately 1l. (ref: photo no.4)post incident actionthe ed immediately went to the location to check the heo, who was in the process of getting out of the truck cab. the heo was not hurtthe ed had asked for the heo’s spill kit to control diesel leaking to grade from the fuel tank the heo notified his supervisor of the incident, the ed notified alpha base (joc), angore base & hgcp transport base of the incident.supervisor arrived on location at ~ 11:30hrs.heo was taken to the hgcp isos clinic for observation and d&a testing (negative sample supplied; pass)security had been mobilised to location to secure assets.a recovery team was informed and attended the location to put in place a recovery plan.fuel from the tank was decanted into drums prior to vehicle recovery.all equipment was recovered safely that evening by the recovery team. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

flood at the offices of the directorate annaba because of an open faucet. migrated from legacy cairs incident #35849normal  0      21      false  false  false    fr  x-none  x-none                                       microsoftinternetexplorer4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                at 8:00workers discovered a flood at the offices of the directorate annaba because ofan open faucet that that security officers have to forget to check.damage recorded:a short circuit in an electric power strip at the level of the methods office.correctiveactions:- the mainshut-off valve must be closed after working hours;- allsecurity officers (sgs) will be made aware of the obligation to isolate all sources(water, electricity) after working hours.- aquestionnaire will be filled out by the security agent for explanation. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: vehicle Incident involving animal, vehicle incident general
text: no fault vehicle incident - wood employee was traveling to location when his vehicle came in contact with a deer. this caused minor damage to the client's vehicle. there were no injuries as a result of the incident. migrated from legacy cairs incident #40199nofault vehicle incident:on december 2, 2018 around 6:30 am, wood employee was traveling to location on county road 80 (near hobson, texas) when his vehicle came in contact with a deer. the impact caused the front grill of the vehicle to break.employee was driving the client vehicle at the time of the incident.there were no injuries as a result of the incident. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

lngp wgpsn maintenance scaffolders were in the process of dismantling an established scaffold of 2 years plus when wasps flew out of the end of a tube and stung two personnel on their left hands. migrated from legacy cairs incident #28686backgroundem maintenance personnel (contracted to em through wgpsn) are required to provide various maintenance services to em operations at the lngp site. on this occasion, a scaffold was required to be dismantled at 95 east common process pipe rack near the flare knock-out line. the scaffold to be dismantled had been in place for a few years. it is a tube and coupler scaffold of approximately 3.0m in height. the ip’s are both qualified as scaffolders. incident detailsthe day started for the scaffolders at the daily prestart meeting facilitated by the maintenance supervisor. personnel then split up into their respective trade work groups to discuss works for the day. the scaffolders had been tasked with dismantling two scaffolds in the common process area. the ip’s injuries were sustained at the second job of the day. the ip’s arrived at the 95 east common process area to dismantle the scaffold. they had a look around the area with no variable hazards identified. the permit pack was reviewed including the swp work at heights checklist, the wms guidelines for erecting and dismantling scaffolding checklist, the lower complexity rescue plan for working at height and the jsa for dismantle scaffold from the hot oil filter area and near flare pipe rack was reviewed and signed on to by the scaffold workgroup. the scaffolders donned their harnesses, gloves, and started to dismantle the scaffold. they were removing some tubes and boards when suddenly paper wasps flew out of the end of one of the tubes and stung two of the scaffolders on their left hands. one scaffolder received one sting, the other scaffolder received four stings. risk assessment complete eptw pack including: · swp work at heights checklist, · wms guidelines for erecting and dismantling scaffolding checklist, · lower complexity rescue plan for working at height · jsa for dismantle scaffold from the hot oil filter area and near flare pipe rack was reviewed and signed on to by the scaffold workgroup. the jsa did not identify the possible hazard of wasps in the area. post incident actionthe ip’s left the area and went to wash their hands and soak them in ice water. the area operator was informed of the situation as was the maintenance supervisor. the ip’s were taken to the clinic for observation and treatment where they received ice packs and ointment. mosquito zone was notified and attended the work area for inspection. identified was a wasp nest within the tube which was eradicated. the ip’s had been wearing flex tuff gloves that have a mechanical rating of 3141. they provide good grip in wet and dry conditions however provide minimal protection against punctures. this is a good learning. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee found door from glass corridor open to the paved area in front of the building in a repeat of cairs incident 20191116, the right-hand door out to the queens steps was open by approximately 4" despite their being a notice on it not to use it. this was escalated from heart obs 201911210. observer closed door and spoke to fm.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury, vehicle incident general
text: nonpreventable vehicle collision. employee pulled to a stop at a red traffic light and was rear-ended by another driver. employee was driving a short-term rental to a project site. other driver at fault. employee experienced pain in the neck, shoulder and left arm. local police department contacted and a police report was filed. employee then consulted with workcare regarding pain. workcare provided self-care, first-aid advice. no further treatment required.

employee slip/trip/fall on same level.  while walking across tripped on wire mesh and fell to his knees and hands.  no reported injury.  employee entered building to hook up valve on riser in order to flush and test water. as he entered, he stepped on the wire mesh for concrete slab pour that was covering the entire sub-floor. as he was walking, a corner of the mesh turned up and tripped the employee. he then fell to his hands and knees. he requested another contractor to get a wood employee to help him up. he was assisted up and stated that he was a little sore but did not need medical attention.  no visible injury and no further complaint of injury.  employee stated that he would treat with advil on his own. commenced investigation.

a project scaffolder was observed walking around the scaffold using the intermediate handrail to walk on. fall protection lanyard was in use a project scaffolder was observed walking around the scaffold using the intermediate handrail to walk on. he moved along the north south end of the scaffold, outside a corner standard and continued to walk along on the intermediate handrail in an east west direction. whilst he was walking along the intermediate hand rail he was straddling the top handrail with a leg on each side. the operative was clipped on with his fall protection lanyard, however the anchor point appeared to be below him on the top handrail.  the job was immediately stopped. initial discussions have been carried out with amec fw and bilfinger salamis management on site.employees have been suspended pending investigation.incident investigation underway.

a wood employee tested positive for covid-19.  a wood employee received a positive covid-19 test result on 7/26/2021.  the wood employee was experiencing symptoms and scheduled a covid 19 test which was a positive result.  contact tracing has been completed. employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19  an employee reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19 to site management. the employee has been in isolation since aug 29. wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed. this is the fifth of five positive results for the 31st  of august.

a hydraulic leak on dow owned digger truck #114396. at the conclusion of the work shift, the wood line crew was disengaging the outriggers on the dow owned digger truck #114396. a small hydraulic leak occurred on the rear-passenger side outrigger. actual/potential decision was based on minimal environmental impact. upon realization of the hydraulic leak, the crew shut off the hydraulic system and began using oil absorbent pads to clean the area. the permit writer was already on scene closing out the permit. dow es&s was called to the scene for an evaluation. they determined the 1 quart spilled did not constitute a reportable environmental event. wood and dow hsse personnel were notified as per protocol.

two wood employees assigned in swp tested positive during the pre mobilization rt-pcr test two wood employees assigned in swp tested positive during their managed quarantine in somerset hotel as requirement for mobilization. they are both currently asymptomatic and is now being monitored by our company oh team. the case was referred to the local government health team for coordination, recording and transfer of facility. the ips is now monitored by wood oh

worker presented himself to contractor clinic with a funghus infection on the foot			 worker reported to the clinic for a foot irritation were he was treated for infection on his toe. worker presented himself to contractor clinic, first aid treatment was applied.

damage to tool trailer door. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30883when eci truck driver went to jobsite in the morning he discoverded the bucket of the backhoe had caused damgae to the tool trailer side access door. the crew that had been working onsite the previuos week had parked the backhoe with the bucket agaisnt the door to secure the trailer over the weekend. at some point while the crew was off the hydraulics of the back hoe bled off causing the bucket to come down and damge the door. besides the door, no further damage was done. the trailer will be repaired in house at the hoad shop. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

ro incident- involves contractor directly engaged by the client. whilst ascending stairs returning to worksite after break ip (broadspectrum) rolled his left ankle. migrated from legacy cairs incident #32107ro incident- involves contractor directly engaged by the client. whilst ascending stairs returning to worksite after break ip (broadspectrum) rolled his left ankle.post smoko and returning to worksite ic crew member was ascending ne stairwell near the "aftercooler" when he rolled his ankle.ip continued normal duties when returning to accommodation module for lunch discomfort hadresolved and reported to hsec.medic treated with ice-pack indoors and ip will be monitored for any further issues.medic interview and feedback:discussed with crew member was he distracted, fatigued, stated no.he checked the stairs all clips and stairs secured and in good condition.medgate case #1666discussed foot positioning on stairs (crew member only places front half of feet on stairs when ascending), advise to place all of foot. maintains and upright stance, control and less stress on ankles, calf's and hips.work boots, to have side zippers up at all times per design and lace up to top part for boot. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

technician fell from a tricycle and injured his knee technician working with operation support was driving a tricycle in fgp area on train 1, he crossed an existing gutter and the front wheel got damaged causing him to fell down from the tricycle. ip was taken to the pob clinic by operations and later to the al khor hospital for further evaluation

reversed a ford flatbed into a toyota hilux causing minor damage. at 1730 26 sep 17 at cease work a linesman was driving a ford flatbed tipper (yt16 axb) which needed to be turned round to enable exit from the thorpe sub station site. the conditions were dry, the light was good and the surface was concrete. to turn round the ford tipper meant reversing had to be carried out, in doing so the tipper was reversed into a toyota hilux (yn14 uxt) which sustained some minor damage to the nearside bumper and bonnet. there where no injuries and after assessing the situation both vehicles were serviceable enough to be driven. drivers involved checked there were no injuries and then assessed the damage to the vehicles, establishing there was only minor damage and that the vehicles were fit to be safely driven away from the scene.

category: foot or leg injury, hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: office worker fell while stepping up a short flight of stairs injuring her wrist migrated from legacy cairs incident #38478ip was walking down a corridor where thereis a two step flight of stairs. as the ip step up onto the first they have lost their footing and fallen forward injuring their right wrist. ip received first aid on siteand then attended a walk in centre where they were examined by a nurse. no specific diagnosis at this time.investigation on going, more information to follow.update 18 aug 18ip started work around 0640 and at approximately 0815 while walking along a corridor lost their footing as they steppe up on the first of a two step flight of stairs. the ip was not carrying anything and does not recall any catalyst or incident that would have caused her to miss their footing. the were no witnesses to the incident. inspection of the area does not indicate any trip hazards.as the ip fell forward they have put out their right hand to break the fall which was bent backwards on the next step as they fell. ips hand was immediately painful. two colleagues came to assist and the ip received first aid. ip was then taken to local walk in centre.ip has since been told that a specific diagnosis is not possible due to the location of the injury. a further diagnosis may be possible at a future date.update 28 aug 18. ip has had confirmation from her doctor that the injury was not a fracture. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

while carrying out routine maintenance on one of the platforms lifeboats, the aft hatch fell closed on the ip’s finger. ip reported straight to the medic migrated from legacy cairs incident #29058cormorant alpha; 21st march 2016 @ 13:15while carrying out routine maintenance on one of the platforms lifeboats, the aft hatch door had been opened to allow the fitting of the isolation pennantsthe ip believed the hatch was resting against the bulkhead. whilst the ip was manoeuvring into position, the hatch dropped closed onto their middle fingerthe ip reported straight to the medica subsequent check revealed that the hatch had not been fully open, it had in fact been resting on a bolt which was protruding from a section of uni-strutthe uni-strut and bolt have since been altered to allow the hatch to fully open and rest on the bulkhead migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

whilst setting up inspection equipment ip fell forward striking a hot pipe causing a minor burn to right hand migrated from legacy cairs incident #33858ip was carrying out inspectionat valero ccr - ip was setting up a gauge for inspection for dft readings in the area and had taken his gloves off to set up the machine. as he was doing so he was kneeling down and subsequently fellforward and placed his hand on un-insulated pipework to stop him falling forward. he was unaware that the pipes were hot and suffered a minor burn to his right palm. ip attended the medical centre where he received first aid - wound cleaned and dressing applied. he returned to normal duties. discussion was held with operative regarding equipment being calibrated prior arrival of the job face - this eliminates the requirement of gloves to be taken off. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

concrete pump truck windscreen external sun protector damaged by retracting boom section 5. the pump truck operator had just completed a concrete pour at 2182 and was packing up the placement boom in readiness to move to another location. during the fold down of the boom which concertinas back into the top of the truck, section 5 has impacted the external sun visor which is mounted above the windscreen. the impact has broken the visor.  the boom was cleared off the vehicle and retracted into position. the supervisor in charge contacted the hse superintendent and reported the event. the scene was preserved and an investigation initiated.

individual tested positive for covid  individual tested positive for covid after tests onshore as he was identified as a cat b (close contact of a cat c). test arranged when arriving onshore as cat b which confirmed positive case.

preventable, company vehicle, minor damage, no injury. employee was traveling west on lebanon road and turning left onto dallas north tollway. a vehicle on employees passenger side came into lane and hit passenger side bumper pushing employee to hit a orange cone on drivers side. employee could not avoid it. the other vehicle fled the scene. reported to donlen, hse personnel reached out to office for additional reporting to be completed.

employee reported being tested positive for covid-19. employee notified supervisor that he tested positive for covid-19 on 4/16/20. the job site the employee has been working on has been shut down since 4/4/20 due to scheduling issues. this employee was in close contact with 2 other employees who are not showing any signs or symptoms of covid-19. the employee is currently self-quarantined at his residence.  hsse was notified and started contacting all the employees that were on the same job site to see if they were showing any signs or symptoms. working on getting a positive confirmation from the employee’s dr to verify the test results.

the employee alleges he was getting out of the vehicle to go into the i&e shop when his right foot slipped.  he said he was able to stop himself from going to the ground.  the employee reported a slight twinge in his back. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30605on monday, june 13, 2016 at 11:05 am at dow freeport a 600 block an infinity maintenance employee alleges he was getting out of the vehicle to go into the i&e shop when his right foot slipped. he said he was able to stop himself from going to the ground. the employee reported to his supervisor a slight twinge in his back.the supervisor notified safety and the employee was taken to us health works. he was seen and released by the doctor with no restrictions. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description
member of project team tested positive for c19 member of renew project team received positive pcr result this morning, ip has not been on wood premises for over one week ip self isolating

wood employee tested positive for covid-19 wood employee (operations technician) tested positive for covid-19 via a pcr test. this is understood to have been a community transmission.  employee undertook self isolation period in line with government requirements.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to slipping  an employee was helping to move a beam when the employee lost footing, slipped, and fell, twisting/breaking an ankle and tearing ligaments. the employee was hospitalized.

category: electric shock or issue, hand or arm injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was on a ladder replacing a fan on an inverter and was shocked. the employee fell off the ladder approximately 2-3 feet to the ground. the employee sustained an electrical burn to the right hand and a fractured spine.

contact with hot objects or substances a prep cook was operating a cooking vessel. the vessel boiled over and hot gravy splashed onto the employee. he suffered second-degree burns on his head, face, arms, hands, and torso.

category: foot or leg injury, vehicle incident general
text: part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident while operating an electrical powered industrial truck, an employee backed into a metal table edge that lacerated his left leg.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee received a compound fracture injury to the middle three fingers of his left hand when the forklift he was changing a tire on slipped from the jack. the employee's hand was caught between the bumper and the tire.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was descending a ladder and stepped down on a hose, breaking the right ankle and requiring surgery.

other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was preparing to put gas in his truck. as he climbed down from his cab, he slipped and fell on the edge of the gas pump's elevated concrete floor, breaking ribs on his left side.

exposure through intact skin, eyes, or other exposed tissue a floor stripping cleaning chemical was spilled onto an employee and the employee received a chemical burn on the left hand and leg and the right foot.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was packing boxes using an electric tape dispenser when the machine became jammed. the employee was attempting to clear the jam when the machine started. the tape dispenser blade then amputated the employee's left index fingertip.

category: dropped object or material, foot or leg injury, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was bending a piece of 1-inch-thick, 6-inch-wide, 6-foot-long flat steel in a press fitted with a four-way die. one of the fins on the die broke, allowing the steel to fall and strike the employee's right leg above the knee. the employee suffered a contusion and swelling and was hospitalized, requiring surgery.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping on uneven surface an employee was in a parking lot, carrying two tubs of mail to her vehicle. her foot caught a crevice between the sidewalk and a curb and she fell, spraining her left ankle and breaking both right ankle bones. she was hospitalized and underwent surgery.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: struck against moving part of machinery or equipment while operating a meat band saw, an employee amputated the tip of his right index finger.  the incident occurred in the cutting room within the meat department.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was signaling for a load to be brought up. the employee's finger was caught between the load line and the sheave of the block, and the employee suffered an amputation of the little finger on the left hand.

category: back injury, hand or arm injury
text: caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation while using a powered roller to form a piece of metal, the employee's glove caught on a piece of metal, pulling his hand into the roller. employee suffered an amputation of the left-hand pointer finger up to the second knuckle and damage to the left-hand thumb, which was stitched back together.

exposure to environmental heat an employee was on a plane returning from fighting a forest fire in arizona when the employee became ill due to heat and dehydration. the employee was hospitalized with a muscle injury.

category: aggressive behaviour, eye injury or irritation
text: hitting, kicking, beating, shoving the injured employee had been taking the orders of drive-through customers. the injured employee was then involved in an altercation with fellow employees and sustained a broken eye socket.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was transferring wire cable from a spool to a cradle. his right-hand middle finger got caught between a washer and a bolt, amputating the distal third of his fingertip. he required reattachment surgery.
caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was repairing a food processor when a blade in it cut his finger. he was hospitalized, requiring surgery.

caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified at 2:00 p.m. on november 14, 2020, an employee reached into an energized airlock underneath the hopper of a baghouse. the guard had rotated out of place and the airlock blades/arms partially amputated the employee's right ring and middle fingertips.
struck by falling part of powered vehicle still attached an employee was hit by a collapsing concrete boom truck, suffering trauma, a severed spine, and paralysis. the employee was hospitalized.

vehicle or machinery fire an employee went to cool the mill temperature and opened the feeder door to apply water when he was engulfed by flames on the feeder deck. he suffered second and third degree burns to 30 percent of his body, including his arms, torso, and head.

category: hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was leaving work for the day. after turning off the lights, he turned to walk out the exit door of the building and tripped over a cart that is used to move supplies and equipment around in the warehouse/docks. he sustained a compound fracture to his right arm, requiring hospitalization and surgery.

category: general injury, head or face injury
text: pedestrian struck by forward-moving vehicle in roadway two employees were walking on facility grounds, in the street, by the 1590 building. they were walking with traffic and one employee was struck by an automobile and was hospitalized with a skull fracture, torn ear that had to be reattached, fractured ribs and lacerations and contusions.

walking, without other incident-single episode a pipeline inspector was walking up a hill when he started having pain in his chest and shoulder. the employee was hospitalized for a potential heart issue.

category: lifting or moving loads, general injury, vehicle incident general
text: nonroadway collision with other vehicle, unspecified an employee was driving a utility vehicle beside a track, towing a small trailer. a railcar mover struck the rear of the trailer, which jackknifed and struck the utility vehicle. the employee suffered fractures to the pelvic region and two ribs.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was cleaning a laminate glue machine when his right thumb became stuck in the machine rollers, amputating his thumb tip.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was pouring cement from a truck when he noticed a hard piece of cement on the conveyor belt. when he attempted to remove the cement, the belt lacerated and broke several of his right-hand fingers.
fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee tripped over a box of fluorescent light bulbs while exiting a maintenance closet. she fell to the ground, injuring her right hip.

category: lifting or moving loads, dropped object or material, foot or leg injury, hand or arm injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was performing maintenance on a tractor-trailer dolly leg when the trailer fell over and crushed the employee's left ring finger, which had to be amputated.
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was holding a 5-gallon bucket while its lid was being cut off with a bandsaw. the saw lacerated the employee's left wrist.
caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was operating a press brake and suffered a crushing injury to the left hand.
struck by object or equipment, unspecified an employee was standing on a steel beam during a re-rigging operation when a steel beam struck his right leg, fracturing his femur.

category: back injury, general injury, fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was retrieving tubing from a pallet. he fell backwards off a nearby edge, landing on the ground about 5.25 feet below and suffering a fractured skull, head lacerations, a broken collarbone, fractured ribs, and a back injury.
exposure to environmental heat an employee became dehydrated (due to the weather) while overseeing a pipeline project.

category: head or face injury, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was painting a wall while standing on a scaffold approximately two feet high. the employee fell off the scaffold and struck his head on the concrete floor. the employee was hospitalized for a skull fracture and brain bleed.
caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was operating a metal shear machine when the blade dropped and amputated his right hand.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was taping knives on the 60" metal slitter machine at the entry side of the machine. when the machine was jogged three fingers on the employee's left hand were amputated.

direct exposure to electricity, unspecified an employee and a co-worker were getting ready to splice underground wires when a screwdriver that had put on a wall made contact with the old wire, causing a flash. the employee suffered burns to their arm, hand, leg, and face that required hospitalization.

ignition of vapors, gases, or liquids on january 13, 2015, the employees were in the process of changing a heater treater tube. the leaking fluid ignited causing severe burn injuries. one employee was sent to the minnesota burn unit.
caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was cleaning/replacing blades on a potato slicer when the slicer caused a partial right thumb amputation.

contact with hot objects or substances two maintenance employees received second degree burns on their torso, legs and arms while troubleshooting a pump that moves ambient air, water and paper stock through a sewer/pipe system. the line/pump was plugged and the pump was shut down. after a period of time where the pump was running (not moving water and paper stock) and plugged, the ambient water and paper stock heated up. the maintenance personnel did not realize that the water had heated (temp unknown at time) and proceeded to open the inspection port. as the inspection port was opened, a sudden release of hot water/paper stock sprayed the two maintenance personnel.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was reaching under a machine bed to fix a motor when a pin on the actuator broke and the bed fell on the employee's hand, fracturing it.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was cleaning out concrete at the bottom of a concrete pump hopper. the pump turned over and caught his fingers, causing partial amputations to two of them. he was hospitalized.

category: lifting or moving loads, general injury, vehicle incident general
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle backing up in nonroadway area an employee was walking when a reversing forklift struck the employee. the employee suffered internal bruising and a hematoma in the abdomen.

category: back injury, general injury, head or face injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to slipping  a pipe burst in the department store and water was leaking onto the floor. an employee slipped on the wet floor and fell hitting her head on the floor. she was hospitalized for pain in her shoulder, neck and lower back.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury, fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee lost sight of the edge of a platform, fell, and landed on his right elbow. his elbow broke and required surgery.
nonclassifiable an employee was taking part in an exercise program when he suffered vision loss.

category: back injury, general injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet an employee was preparing to conduct welding on a row of u-shaped piping. he was walking on a plank board placed in the saddle of the "u" when the board flipped. he fell about 10 feet to the ground below, suffering fractures to the back and neck.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified on 11/23/16, at about 12:30 p.m., an employee was working on a trash compactor and caught his right leg fracturing the shin. he was taken to hospital where he received surgery.
caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was attempting to clear a jam on a machine when the blade came down and cut her left middle finger.

category: foot or leg injury, vehicle incident general
text: part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident an employee was operating a pallet jack when the employee's left leg hit a pole, resulting in a left ankle fracture.

struck by dislodged flying object, particle employees were clearing mangroves along the shore on pearl harbor. when the cut mangroves were being pulled to shore, the rope broke, and the pulley struck an employee in the head.

direct exposure to electricity, greater than 220 volts on 9/27/2016, at approximately 3:44 p.m., an employee was performing foundation concrete forming work when he was struck by lightning and suffered burns, requiring hospitalization.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee fell down the stairs while carrying a box from the stock room.

contact with hot objects or substances an employee was performing metal casting work with molten steel when molten metal spilled onto his right leg and into his boot, burning his foot. leg protection was not worn at the time of the incident.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment employee was injured while repairing a forklift in the receiving department. the employee was caught between the forklift's mast and cage while reconnecting a hose. the employee was hospitalized overnight with a crushed or bruised vertebrae.

category: foot or leg injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was on a ladder repairing an overhead vacuum hose when the employee fell from the ladder and fractured the left ankle.

category: foot or leg injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was coming down a straight ladder, missed a rung and fell less than two feet fracturing a knee cap.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level 16 to 20 feet an employee fell about 20 feet from an aerial lift while pulling cables.

exposure to environmental heat after working in the heat for the past 2.5 days, an employee experienced excessive sweating and occasional vomiting and nausea. he was hospitalized for dehydration and a muscle injury.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury, hand or arm injury, head or face injury, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was securing a load on a flatbed trailer and slipped off the trailer to the ground. the employee sustained a fractured wrist, dislocated shoulder and a head laceration.

direct exposure to electricity, unspecified after performing a welding operation inside of a tank, an employee was exiting the tank when his leg caused a welding lead to short against the side of the tank and an electric arc occurred. his leg was burned, requiring hospitalization.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was lowering a catering box onto a truck chassis when her pinky finger was caught between the frame of the truck and the guard on the back of the truck cab. her pinky fingertip was partially amputated.

category: foot or leg injury, general injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level, unspecified an employee was using a non-powered manual pallet jack to reposition a loaded pallet. the employee stepped back from the pallet and fell on the concrete floor. the employee was hospitalized with injuries to the right hip and leg.

fall on same level due to slipping  at approximately 11:15, an employee was stepping up onto a curb in front of the elevator lobby on the g2 level of the garage when he slipped on a wet walkway and fell onto his knees. after he fell, he could not bend his knees or get up. he tore a knee tendon and was hospitalized.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was using a meat grinder to tenderize round steaks when her gloved left hand became caught in the blades. the employee sustained lacerations and torn tendons.

other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was taking inventory inside a 48-foot tractor trailer. she had one foot inside the trailer and one foot on the power dock plate when a truck jockey hooked up to the trailer in error and pulled away.  this action caused the employee to fall 4 feet off the back of the trailer. she landed on her feet and sustained bi-lateral heel fractures.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was assembling rings into plastic tubes. the employee ran out of large plastic tubes and went to the crib area storage to retrieve more. the employee climbed onto a rolling ladder and fell off, sustaining fractures.
other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee fell 3 feet from an auto frame machine resulting in a head injury.
exposure to electricity, unspecified an employee was shocked while working on the roof.
fall on same level due to slipping  an employee was walking outside to service a recycling bin when he slipped on ice and broke his left hip.
